trans-unit.source: Creating a New Filter Driver
trans-unit.target: Creating a New Filter Driver

trans-unit.source: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new filter driver.
trans-unit.target: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new filter driver.

trans-unit.source: Filter drivers are different from device function drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.
trans-unit.target: Filter drivers are different from device function drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.

trans-unit.source: To learn about filter drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see the following topics.
trans-unit.target: To learn about filter drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see the following topics.

trans-unit.source: What is a Driver?
trans-unit.target: What is a Driver?

trans-unit.source: Choosing a Driver Model
trans-unit.target: Choosing a Driver Model

trans-unit.source: Device Nodes and Device Stacks
trans-unit.target: Device Nodes and Device Stacks

trans-unit.source: Filter Drivers
trans-unit.target: Filter Drivers

trans-unit.source: Types of WDM Drivers
trans-unit.target: Types of WDM Drivers

trans-unit.source: To begin, first determine which driver model is appropriate for your filter driver.
trans-unit.target: To begin, first determine which driver model is appropriate for your filter driver.

trans-unit.source: For help determining which model is best for you, see [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652).
trans-unit.target: For help determining which model is best for you, see [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652).

trans-unit.source: If you are writing a filter driver for a hardware device, determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in [Device and Driver Technologies](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff557557).
trans-unit.target: If you are writing a filter driver for a hardware device, determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in [Device and Driver Technologies](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff557557).

trans-unit.source: See the documentation for that particular technology to see whether there is any guidance for choosing a filter driver model.
trans-unit.target: See the documentation for that particular technology to see whether there is any guidance for choosing a filter driver model.

trans-unit.source: The recommended filter driver model varies from one technology to the next.
trans-unit.target: The recommended filter driver model varies from one technology to the next.

trans-unit.source: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF), the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF), or the Windows Driver Model (WDM).
trans-unit.target: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF), the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF), or the Windows Driver Model (WDM).

trans-unit.source: For other technologies, the documentation gives explicit details on how to write a filter driver.
trans-unit.target: For other technologies, the documentation gives explicit details on how to write a filter driver.

trans-unit.source: Some technologies have mini filter models.
trans-unit.target: Some technologies have mini filter models.

trans-unit.source: For some technologies, there might not be any recommendation for a filter driver model.
trans-unit.target: For some technologies, there might not be any recommendation for a filter driver model.

trans-unit.source: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:
trans-unit.target: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:

trans-unit.source: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.
trans-unit.target: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF**.

trans-unit.source: In the middle pane, select **User Mode Driver (UMDF)**.
trans-unit.target: In the middle pane, select **User Mode Driver (UMDF)**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439659).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439659).

trans-unit.source: **Note** When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: **Note** When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
trans-unit.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.

trans-unit.source: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.
trans-unit.target: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **WDF**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **WDF**.

trans-unit.source: In the middle pane, select **Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)**.
trans-unit.target: In the middle pane, select **Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).

trans-unit.source: **Note** When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: **Note** When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
trans-unit.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.

trans-unit.source: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a specific filter or mini filter model.
trans-unit.target: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a specific filter or mini filter model.

trans-unit.source: If your device technology has a specific filter or minifilter model, check to see if Visual Studio has a template for the model.
trans-unit.target: If your device technology has a specific filter or minifilter model, check to see if Visual Studio has a template for the model.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver**.

trans-unit.source: Browse the list of installed templates to see whether there is a template for the type of filter you need to write.
trans-unit.target: Browse the list of installed templates to see whether there is a template for the type of filter you need to write.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might choose the **Filter Driver: NDIS** template under **Networking**.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might choose the **Filter Driver: NDIS** template under **Networking**.

trans-unit.source: If there is no template for your type of filter driver under **Windows Driver**, click **Online** and browse the templates that are available online.
trans-unit.target: If there is no template for your type of filter driver under **Windows Driver**, click **Online** and browse the templates that are available online.

trans-unit.source: If you find a template for your type of filter driver, select the template, fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: If you find a template for your type of filter driver, select the template, fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your filter driver.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your filter driver.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your filter.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: If your device technology has a specific filter model or a minifilter model, and you can't find a template for your type of filter driver, refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance to determine whether to use UMDF, KMDF, or WDM.
trans-unit.target: If your device technology has a specific filter model or a minifilter model, and you can't find a template for your type of filter driver, refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance to determine whether to use UMDF, KMDF, or WDM.

trans-unit.source: Case 4: The documentation for your technology recommends WDM.
trans-unit.target: Case 4: The documentation for your technology recommends WDM.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select **WDM.**
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select **WDM.**

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose **Add | New Item**.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose **Add | New Item**.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, select **C++ File (.cpp)**, enter a name for your file, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, select **C++ File (.cpp)**, enter a name for your file, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: **Note** If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the **.c** extension.
trans-unit.target: **Note** If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the **.c** extension.

trans-unit.source: Implement the functions required by your filter.
trans-unit.target: Implement the functions required by your filter.

trans-unit.source: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.
trans-unit.target: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.

trans-unit.source: Case 5: The documentation for your technology does not have a recommendation for a filter driver model.
trans-unit.target: Case 5: The documentation for your technology does not have a recommendation for a filter driver model.

trans-unit.source: Determine whether UMDF, KMDF, or WDM is the best model for your filter driver.
trans-unit.target: Determine whether UMDF, KMDF, or WDM is the best model for your filter driver.

trans-unit.source: For help, see [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652).
trans-unit.target: For help, see [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652).

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select one of the following templates:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select one of the following templates:

trans-unit.source: WDF | User Mode Driver (UMDF)
trans-unit.target: WDF | User Mode Driver (UMDF)

trans-unit.source: WDF | Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)
trans-unit.target: WDF | Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)

trans-unit.source: WDM | Empty Kernel Driver
trans-unit.target: WDM | Empty Kernel Driver

trans-unit.source: **Note** When you create a new KMDF or UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: **Note** When you create a new KMDF or UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
trans-unit.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

trans-unit.source: Implement the functions required by your filter.
trans-unit.target: Implement the functions required by your filter.

trans-unit.source: Create new .c or .cpp files as needed.
trans-unit.target: Create new .c or .cpp files as needed.

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure which template to use, consider reading or posting to the [Windows Hardware WDK and Driver Development](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p?LinkID=252169) forum.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure which template to use, consider reading or posting to the [Windows Hardware WDK and Driver Development](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p?LinkID=252169) forum.
